issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A fix has been committed, and will be part of the next release
status.name: Release Pending

fields.description:
Below is the output from the unpack with all the evidence to show the differences

One example error:
libvirt: Storage Driver error : Cannot access storage file '/dev/disk/by-id/scsi-1IET_000a0001' (as uid:107, gid:107): No such file or directory

This volume was referenced by libvirt domain at the location above. On the destination host to be unpacked is now located at /dev/disk/by-id/scsi-1IET_00130001

These values are correlated by the iqn store number, evidence below:
Source/pack/centos6:
iqn=iqn.2009-06.com.eucalyptus.one:store10
dev=/dev/disk/by-id/scsi-1IET_000a0001

10 base10=A base16

Destination/unpack/centos7
iqn=iqn.2009-06.com.eucalyptus.one:store19
dev=/dev/disk/by-id/scsi-1IET_00130001

19 base10=13 base16

{noformat}
[root@a-16-r myinstances]# ll
total 107008
drwxr-xr-x. 2 root root     4096 Jul 21 12:33 bad_1st_try
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 55660851 Jul 21 08:53 i-0ac05ae0-pack.tgz
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 53862956 Jul 21 09:07 i-5f9c62a5-pack.tgz
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root    31860 Jul 21 11:30 nodeadmin-pack-instance_out.txt
drwxr-xr-x. 2 root root     4096 Jul 21 12:33 svcinst_maybe
drwxr-xr-x. 2 root root     4096 Jul 21 16:32 temp
[root@a-16-r myinstances]# for x in i-*
> do
> echo $x
> done
i-0ac05ae0-pack.tgz
i-5f9c62a5-pack.tgz
[root@a-16-r myinstances]# for x in i-*; do echo $x ----------------------------------------------------------------; nodeadmin-unpack-instance --verbose --sc-host-port 10.111.5.60:8773 $x; done

fields.summary: nodeadmin-unpack-instance fails for attached ebs volumes with DAS

comments.body:
This is actually a problem because saving the libvirt instance to disk, save ram to disk, takes a snapshot of the domain definition with libvirt and saves alongside the ram.

Using a local symlink similar to the instance storage devices/files would help alleviate this problem as the file would exist and we could fix up the link prior to restoring.
The issue was observed with DAS EBS backend and may even extend to Overlay both of which utilize tgt framework for creating iscsi targets

We may have a root cause why online migration works and offline migration (pack/unpack) is broken for DAS EBS backend. Online and offline migrations are modeled almost similarly. But they differ in the order of operations between the NC and SC. Here is a high level overview of sequence between NC and SC

Online migration: Starts with EBS volume exported to source NC --> Export volume is fired from destination NC to SC: DAS backend finds an existing iscsi target since the volume is exported to an NC and reuses it --> Un-export volume is fired from source NC to SC: DAS backend does not tear down the iscsi target since it is exported to an NC

Offline migration: Starts with EBS volume exported to source NC --> Un-export volume is fired from source NC to SC: DAS backend tears down iscsi target since it is not exported to any NCs --> Export volume is fired from destination NC to SC: DAS backend reconstructs the iscsi target

Reconstructed iscsi targets don‚Äôt share the same identifier as their previous incarnations which is by design for DAS and Overlay EBS backends using tgt framework.

Testing removing calling disconnect/unexport during pack shows successful unpack.

The support in the CLI, nodeadmin-manage-volume-connections DisconnectVolumes -s sc-host-port -i instance-id, to disconnect both client and server side clean if the originating node controller is not destroyed via an OS upgrade.

This should handle cleanup in the unlikely event the originating node controller is reused.
This should have been sent earlier.
Proven with latest DAS upgrade testing.
